abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was rated
            satisfactory, and all of its objectives were met. A
            successful reform program, which involved the restructuring
            of the sector, gave way to a highly satisfactory Government
            performance, including significant changes to the legal and
            regulatory frameworks, as well as initial progress in
            privatization and liberalization. The lessons learned
            suggest that the provision of quality advice the Bank offers
            in support of sector reform programs, is today, its primary
            asset; for it was at the preparation of the project, when
            financial leverage was high, that important reform steps
            were taken, allowing the Borrower, Telekomunikacja Polska
            S.A. (TPSA) to improve its financial position and to access
            new financial sources. However, as TPSA became stronger,
            both operationally and commercially, and developed supply
            relationships, it became apparent that the Bank's
            procurement guidelines - which require an International
            Competitive Bidding process - are too time-consuming. This
            suggests, that under certain circumstances, the Bank's
            procurement guidelines may not be compatible with those
            practices of successful commercial enterprises, making the
            process unattractive to them. Loan covenants can be
            constraining, particularly as a borrower achieves new
            financial strength, and moves from a state enterprise to
            commercial business, thus the need arises to amend/waive
            covenants accordingly.

5082098.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rural development,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
The project emphasizes and supports: (a)
            strengthening and expansion of the national trunk network
            and selected improvements in the international network and
            in local networks in order to rapidly decongest and improve
            telecommunication services for business; (b) increased
            efficiency in telecommunications operations; and (c)
            improved quality of services.  The project consists of:  (a)
            investments in an overlay digital long-distance network
            connecting 17 major urban nodes plus expansion of
            international connections and selected investment in local
            networks; and (b) technical assistance and training.  The
            latter focuses on improving the accounting and management
            information systems, traffic engineering, software
            development and maintenance, human resource development and training.
